00007 /*
00008  * random.c:
00009  * An improved random number generation package.  In addition to the standard
00010  * rand()/srand() like interface, this package also has a special state info
00011  * interface.  The initstate() routine is called with a seed, an array of
00012  * bytes, and a count of how many bytes are being passed in; this array is then
00013  * initialized to contain information for random number generation with that
00014  * much state information.  Good sizes for the amount of state information are
00015  * 32, 64, 128, and 256 bytes.  The state can be switched by calling the
00016  * setstate() routine with the same array as was initiallized with initstate().
00017  * By default, the package runs with 128 bytes of state information and
00018  * generates far better random numbers than a linear congruential generator.
00019  * If the amount of state information is less than 32 bytes, a simple linear
00020  * congruential R.N.G. is used.
00021  * Internally, the state information is treated as an array of longs; the
00022  * zeroeth element of the array is the type of R.N.G. being used (small
00023  * integer); the remainder of the array is the state information for the
00024  * R.N.G.  Thus, 32 bytes of state information will give 7 longs worth of
00025  * state information, which will allow a degree seven polynomial.  (Note: the 
00026  * zeroeth word of state information also has some other information stored
00027  * in it -- see setstate() for details).
00028  * The random number generation technique is a linear feedback shift register
00029  * approach, employing trinomials (since there are fewer terms to sum up that
00030  * way).  In this approach, the least significant bit of all the numbers in
00031  * the state table will act as a linear feedback shift register, and will have
00032  * period 2^deg - 1 (where deg is the degree of the polynomial being used,
00033  * assuming that the polynomial is irreducible and primitive).  The higher
00034  * order bits will have longer periods, since their values are also influenced
00035  * by pseudo-random carries out of the lower bits.  The total period of the
00036  * generator is approximately deg*(2**deg - 1); thus doubling the amount of
00037  * state information has a vast influence on the period of the generator.
00038  * Note: the deg*(2**deg - 1) is an approximation only good for large deg,
00039  * when the period of the shift register is the dominant factor.  With deg
00040  * equal to seven, the period is actually much longer than the 7*(2**7 - 1)
00041  * predicted by this formula.
00042  */
00043 
00044 
00045 
00046 /*
00047  * For each of the currently supported random number generators, we have a
00048  * break value on the amount of state information (you need at least this
00049  * many bytes of state info to support this random number generator), a degree
00050  * for the polynomial (actually a trinomial) that the R.N.G. is based on, and
00051  * the separation between the two lower order coefficients of the trinomial.
00052  */
00053 
00054 #define         TYPE_0          0               
00055 #define         BREAK_0         8
00056 #define         DEG_0           0
00057 #define         SEP_0           0
00058 
00059 #define         TYPE_1          1               
00060 #define         BREAK_1         32
00061 #define         DEG_1           7
00062 #define         SEP_1           3
00063 
00064 #define         TYPE_2          2               
00065 #define         BREAK_2         64
00066 #define         DEG_2           15
00067 #define         SEP_2           1
00068 
00069 #define         TYPE_3          3               
00070 #define         BREAK_3         128
00071 #define         DEG_3           31
00072 #define         SEP_3           3
00073 
00074 #define         TYPE_4          4               
00075 #define         BREAK_4         256
00076 #define         DEG_4           63
00077 #define         SEP_4           1

00080 /*
00081  * Array versions of the above information to make code run faster -- relies
00082  * on fact that TYPE_i == i.
00083  */

00085 #define         MAX_TYPES       5               
00087 static struct _randomjunk {
00088         int     degrees[MAX_TYPES];
00089         int     seps[MAX_TYPES];
00090         long    randtbl[ DEG_3 + 1 ];
00091 /*
00092  * fptr and rptr are two pointers into the state info, a front and a rear
00093  * pointer.  These two pointers are always rand_sep places aparts, as they cycle
00094  * cyclically through the state information.  (Yes, this does mean we could get
00095  * away with just one pointer, but the code for random() is more efficient this
00096  * way).  The pointers are left positioned as they would be from the call
00097  *                      initstate( 1, randtbl, 128 )
00098  * (The position of the rear pointer, rptr, is really 0 (as explained above
00099  * in the initialization of randtbl) because the state table pointer is set
00100  * to point to randtbl[1] (as explained below).
00101  */
00102         long    *fptr, *rptr;
00103 /*
00104  * The following things are the pointer to the state information table,
00105  * the type of the current generator, the degree of the current polynomial
00106  * being used, and the separation between the two pointers.
00107  * Note that for efficiency of random(), we remember the first location of
00108  * the state information, not the zeroeth.  Hence it is valid to access
00109  * state[-1], which is used to store the type of the R.N.G.
00110  * Also, we remember the last location, since this is more efficient than
00111  * indexing every time to find the address of the last element to see if
00112  * the front and rear pointers have wrapped.
00113  */
00114         long    *state;
00115         int     rand_type, rand_deg, rand_sep;
00116         long    *end_ptr;
00117 } *__randomjunk, *_randomjunk(), _randominit = {
00118         /*
00119          * Initially, everything is set up as if from :
00120          *              initstate( 1, &randtbl, 128 );
00121          * Note that this initialization takes advantage of the fact
00122          * that srandom() advances the front and rear pointers 10*rand_deg
00123          * times, and hence the rear pointer which starts at 0 will also
00124          * end up at zero; thus the zeroeth element of the state
00125          * information, which contains info about the current
00126          * position of the rear pointer is just
00127          *      MAX_TYPES*(rptr - state) + TYPE_3 == TYPE_3.
00128          */
00129         { DEG_0, DEG_1, DEG_2, DEG_3, DEG_4 },
00130         { SEP_0, SEP_1, SEP_2, SEP_3, SEP_4 },
00131         { TYPE_3,
00132             0x9a319039, 0x32d9c024, 0x9b663182, 0x5da1f342, 
00133             0xde3b81e0, 0xdf0a6fb5, 0xf103bc02, 0x48f340fb, 
00134             0x7449e56b, 0xbeb1dbb0, 0xab5c5918, 0x946554fd, 
00135             0x8c2e680f, 0xeb3d799f, 0xb11ee0b7, 0x2d436b86, 
00136             0xda672e2a, 0x1588ca88, 0xe369735d, 0x904f35f7, 
00137             0xd7158fd6, 0x6fa6f051, 0x616e6b96, 0xac94efdc, 
00138             0x36413f93, 0xc622c298, 0xf5a42ab8, 0x8a88d77b, 
00139                         0xf5ad9d0e, 0x8999220b, 0x27fb47b9 },
00140         &_randominit.randtbl[ SEP_3 + 1 ],
00141         &_randominit.randtbl[ 1 ],
00142         &_randominit.randtbl[ 1 ],
00143         TYPE_3, DEG_3, SEP_3,
00144         &_randominit.randtbl[ DEG_3 + 1]
00145 };

00147 static struct _randomjunk *
00148 _randomjunk()
00149 {
00150         register struct _randomjunk *rp = __randomjunk;
00151 
00152         if (rp == 0) {
00153                 rp = (struct _randomjunk *)malloc(sizeof (*rp));
00154                 if (rp == 0)
00155                         return (0);
00156                 *rp = _randominit;
00157                 __randomjunk = rp;
00158         }
00159         return (rp);
00160 }

00162 /*
00163  * srandom:
00164  * Initialize the random number generator based on the given seed.  If the
00165  * type is the trivial no-state-information type, just remember the seed.
00166  * Otherwise, initializes state[] based on the given "seed" via a linear
00167  * congruential generator.  Then, the pointers are set to known locations
00168  * that are exactly rand_sep places apart.  Lastly, it cycles the state
00169  * information a given number of times to get rid of any initial dependencies
00170  * introduced by the L.C.R.N.G.
00171  * Note that the initialization of randtbl[] for default usage relies on
00172  * values produced by this routine.
00173  */
00174 
00175 srandom( x )
00176 
00177     unsigned            x;
00178 {
00179         register struct _randomjunk *rp = _randomjunk();
00180         register  int           i, j;
00181 
00182         if (rp == 0)
00183                 return;
00184         if(  rp->rand_type  ==  TYPE_0  )  {
00185             rp->state[ 0 ] = x;
00186         }
00187         else  {
00188             j = 1;
00189             rp->state[ 0 ] = x;
00190             for( i = 1; i < rp->rand_deg; i++ )  {
00191                 rp->state[i] = 1103515245*rp->state[i - 1] + 12345;
00192             }
00193             rp->fptr = &rp->state[ rp->rand_sep ];
00194             rp->rptr = &rp->state[ 0 ];
00195             for( i = 0; i < 10*rp->rand_deg; i++ )  random();
00196         }
00197 }

00201 /*
00202  * initstate:
00203  * Initialize the state information in the given array of n bytes for
00204  * future random number generation.  Based on the number of bytes we
00205  * are given, and the break values for the different R.N.G.'s, we choose
00206  * the best (largest) one we can and set things up for it.  srandom() is
00207  * then called to initialize the state information.
00208  * Note that on return from srandom(), we set state[-1] to be the type
00209  * multiplexed with the current value of the rear pointer; this is so
00210  * successive calls to initstate() won't lose this information and will
00211  * be able to restart with setstate().
00212  * Note: the first thing we do is save the current state, if any, just like
00213  * setstate() so that it doesn't matter when initstate is called.
00214  * Returns a pointer to the old state.
00215  */
00216 
00217 char  *
00218 initstate( seed, arg_state, n )
00219 
00220     unsigned            seed;                   /* seed for R. N. G. */
00221     char                *arg_state;             /* pointer to state array */
00222     int                 n;                      /* # bytes of state info */
00223 {
00224         register struct _randomjunk *rp = _randomjunk();
00225         register  char          *ostate;
00226 
00227         if (rp == 0)
00228                 return (0);
00229         ostate = (char *)( &rp->state[ -1 ] );
00230 
00231         if(  rp->rand_type  ==  TYPE_0  )  rp->state[ -1 ] = rp->rand_type;
00232         else  rp->state[ -1 ] =
00233             MAX_TYPES*(rp->rptr - rp->state) + rp->rand_type;
00234         if(  n  <  BREAK_1  )  {
00235             if(  n  <  BREAK_0  )  {
00236                 fprintf( stderr, "initstate: not enough state (%d bytes) with which to do jack; ignored.\n" );
00237                 return (0);
00238             }
00239             rp->rand_type = TYPE_0;
00240             rp->rand_deg = DEG_0;
00241             rp->rand_sep = SEP_0;
00242         }
00243         else  {
00244             if(  n  <  BREAK_2  )  {
00245                 rp->rand_type = TYPE_1;
00246                 rp->rand_deg = DEG_1;
00247                 rp->rand_sep = SEP_1;
00248             }
00249             else  {
00250                 if(  n  <  BREAK_3  )  {
00251                     rp->rand_type = TYPE_2;
00252                     rp->rand_deg = DEG_2;
00253                     rp->rand_sep = SEP_2;
00254                 }
00255                 else  {
00256                     if(  n  <  BREAK_4  )  {
00257                         rp->rand_type = TYPE_3;
00258                         rp->rand_deg = DEG_3;
00259                         rp->rand_sep = SEP_3;
00260                     }
00261                     else  {
00262                         rp->rand_type = TYPE_4;
00263                         rp->rand_deg = DEG_4;
00264                         rp->rand_sep = SEP_4;
00265                     }
00266                 }
00267             }
00268         }
00269         rp->state = &(  ( (long *)arg_state )[1]  );    /* first location */
00270         rp->end_ptr = &rp->state[ rp->rand_deg ];       /* must set end_ptr before srandom */
00271         srandom( seed );
00272         if(  rp->rand_type  ==  TYPE_0  )  rp->state[ -1 ] = rp->rand_type;
00273         else  rp->state[ -1 ] = MAX_TYPES*(rp->rptr - rp->state) + rp->rand_type;
00274         return( ostate );
00275 }

00279 /*
00280  * setstate:
00281  * Restore the state from the given state array.
00282  * Note: it is important that we also remember the locations of the pointers
00283  * in the current state information, and restore the locations of the pointers
00284  * from the old state information.  This is done by multiplexing the pointer
00285  * location into the zeroeth word of the state information.
00286  * Note that due to the order in which things are done, it is OK to call
00287  * setstate() with the same state as the current state.
00288  * Returns a pointer to the old state information.
00289  */
00290 
00291 char  *
00292 setstate( arg_state )
00293 
00294     char                *arg_state;
00295 {
00296         register struct _randomjunk *rp = _randomjunk();
00297         register  long          *new_state;
00298         register  int           type;
00299         register  int           rear;
00300         char                    *ostate;
00301 
00302         if (rp == 0)
00303                 return (0);
00304         new_state = (long *)arg_state;
00305         type = new_state[0]%MAX_TYPES;
00306         rear = new_state[0]/MAX_TYPES;
00307         ostate = (char *)( &rp->state[ -1 ] );
00308 
00309         if(  rp->rand_type  ==  TYPE_0  )  rp->state[ -1 ] = rp->rand_type;
00310         else  rp->state[ -1 ] = MAX_TYPES*(rp->rptr - rp->state) + rp->rand_type;
00311         switch(  type  )  {
00312             case  TYPE_0:
00313             case  TYPE_1:
00314             case  TYPE_2:
00315             case  TYPE_3:
00316             case  TYPE_4:
00317                 rp->rand_type = type;
00318                 rp->rand_deg = rp->degrees[ type ];
00319                 rp->rand_sep = rp->seps[ type ];
00320                 break;
00321 
00322             default:
00323                 fprintf( stderr, "setstate: state info has been munged; not changed.\n" );
00324         }
00325         rp->state = &new_state[ 1 ];
00326         if(  rp->rand_type  !=  TYPE_0  )  {
00327             rp->rptr = &rp->state[ rear ];
00328             rp->fptr = &rp->state[ (rear + rp->rand_sep)%rp->rand_deg ];
00329         }
00330         rp->end_ptr = &rp->state[ rp->rand_deg ];       /* set end_ptr too */
00331         return( ostate );
00332 }

00336 /*
00337  * random:
00338  * If we are using the trivial TYPE_0 R.N.G., just do the old linear
00339  * congruential bit.  Otherwise, we do our fancy trinomial stuff, which is the
00340  * same in all ther other cases due to all the global variables that have been
00341  * set up.  The basic operation is to add the number at the rear pointer into
00342  * the one at the front pointer.  Then both pointers are advanced to the next
00343  * location cyclically in the table.  The value returned is the sum generated,
00344  * reduced to 31 bits by throwing away the "least random" low bit.
00345  * Note: the code takes advantage of the fact that both the front and
00346  * rear pointers can't wrap on the same call by not testing the rear
00347  * pointer if the front one has wrapped.
00348  * Returns a 31-bit random number.
00349  */
00350 
00351 long
00352 random()
00353 {
00354         register struct _randomjunk *rp = _randomjunk();
00355         long            i;
00356         
00357         if (rp == 0)
00358                 return (0);
00359         if(  rp->rand_type  ==  TYPE_0  )  {
00360             i = rp->state[0] = ( rp->state[0]*1103515245 + 12345 )&0x7fffffff;
00361         }
00362         else  {
00363             *rp->fptr += *rp->rptr;
00364             i = (*rp->fptr >> 1)&0x7fffffff;    /* chucking least random bit */
00365             if(  ++rp->fptr  >=  rp->end_ptr  )  {
00366                 rp->fptr = rp->state;
00367                 ++rp->rptr;
00368             }
00369             else  {
00370                 if(  ++rp->rptr  >=  rp->end_ptr  )  rp->rptr = rp->state;
00371             }
00372         }
00373         return( i );
00374 }
